awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Photonic spectrum splitting with nanocrystal luminophores
awd_abstract_narration:
The sun represents the most abundant potential source of sustainable energy on earth.  Solar cells that capture the sun?s rays and convert this energy into electricity can potentially be improved through the science of photonics, which uses advanced materials to guide the light pathway through the device. This project will develop photonic structures which contain nanocrystal-polymer composite materials that split and concentrate the solar spectrum into its component wavelengths, and then direct the concentrated specific wavelengths to semiconductor materials that are best able to convert these wavelength energies into electricity. Through the combination of these processes, the overall efficiency for solar energy conversion can be increased.  The proposed research targets designs that can be readily implemented with existing solar cell fabrication processes and could also be integrated into architectural features for buildings. These photonic materials may also find other applications in biological imaging for medical diagnostics, solid-state lighting, and display technology.  This project also has broad educational goals coupled to the research activities, aimed at encouraging women and underrepresented minorities into STEM careers through project-based learning about solar energy.

This project will address a fundamental challenge in solar photovoltaic conversion of sunlight to electricity - the mismatch between the broad solar spectrum and semiconductors that only efficiently convert light at wavelengths near their bandgap energy.  In conventional multi-junction solar cells, the light must transfer through a stack of semiconductor layers designed to capture a portion of the solar spectrum.  The transfer of light through this stack results in absorption losses that lower the theoretically-attainable solar energy conversion efficiency.   The splitting of the solar spectrum into component wavelengths and the direction of these wavelengths to adjacent semiconductors, as opposed to within a stack, can reduce losses and improve solar energy conversion efficiency.  The overall goal of the proposed research is to develop an efficient spectrum splitting system for enhancing solar energy harvesting using optical materials that combine photonic structures with luminescent nanocrystal-polymer composite materials.  Towards this end, the proposed research seeks to gain a fundamental understanding of the interaction of these nanocomposite materials with various photonic structures for harvesting of light.  The research plan has three primary objectives. The first objective is to consider photonic routes for enhancing the efficiency of solar spectrum splitting based on nanocomposite luminescent concentrators.  For example, by incorporating light trapping elements such as Bragg mirrors into luminescent concentrators, luminophore quantum yield can be increased.  The second objective will address loss mechanisms by tuning the properties of luminescent nanocrystal-polymer composite materials.  For example, a photonic crystal consisting of alternating high index and low index nanocrystal-polymer composites could reduce losses within the luminescent concentrator.   In the third objective, photonic nanocrystal-polymer composite materials will be integrated into single-junction solar photovoltaic cells to serve as luminescent concentrators that provide controlled angles of emission, reduced absorption loss, and enhanced radiative decay rate. The design principles established through the single-junction device will be used to develop a spectrum splitting and concentrating system for multi-junction solar cells that harvest a larger fraction of the solar spectrum using nanocrystal luminophores engineered with different bandgaps. Theoretical approaches will link nanoscale properties and photonic structures to their performance as waveguides that accept diffuse sunlight and direct it to adjacent solar cells. This information will used to predict the upper limits of efficiency for single and multi-junction solar cells.  Experimental work will include synthesis of nanocrystal-polymer composites, correlation of the composite nanostructure to optical response, and fabrication of photonic structures.  Optical spectroscopy and electron microscopy will be used to characterize the light propagation inside the concentrators. The proposed research is integrated with educational activities that focus on project-based learning about solar energy across educational and outreach platforms, including the development of introductory lecture and laboratory coursework materials, the creation of a program for undergraduate women to learn about undergraduate research opportunities in solar and related sustainable energy systems, and outreach to K-12 students that emphasizes the role of engineering in addressing societal goals.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed light management structures for luminescent solar concentrators, or LSCs. LSCs are semi-transparent structures that absorb incident sunlight, re-emit it at selected wavelengths, and direct the emitted light onto an adjacent solar cell. In this fashion, spectrally broad and diffuse sunlight is captured and transformed into wavelengths that are efficiently converted to electricity by the solar cell. Since the LSC is semi-transparent, it can be incorporated into windows (including buildings and greenhouses) and other architectural facades. However, there are challenges in light management that have limited the development of efficient LSCs, including the need to direct light onto the solar cell and minimize light propagation in undesirable directions, and the need to efficiently harvest the incident sunlight. 

 

In this project, we developed various photonic architectures for LSCs. We designed and studied spectrally-selective mirrors that can be incorporated on top of the LSC, such that blue light is transmitted and the luminescent red light is reflected and trapped inside the LSC. There is an inherent balance here on whether it is more important to transmit as much light as possible, or to capture the luminescent light; our project enumerated several design principles that provide insight into this tradeoff for a range of different candidate luminophore properties. 

 

Our project has particularly focused on nanocrystals as light-emitting materials, which can be synthesized to be highly luminescent and exhibit desirable/tailorable absorption and luminescence spectra. Embedding these materials in polymers can be challenging, as aggregation leads to increased light scattering. We examined this light management problem in several different contexts. For the case of Si nanocrystals embedded in poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), we studied the impact of light scattering as a function of LSC size. We also studied thin film composites of Si in PMMA, which showed higher loading fractions of nanocrystals were possible compared to their bulk counterparts. Other work studied an alternative matrix material, poly(cyclohexylethylene) (PCHE), showing that nanocrystals embedded in this system preserve their optical properties with little haze. 

 

With this combination of available materials, we created tandem LSCs by stacking multiple layers of different nanocrystals on top of each other. This allows for full spectrum coverage, since different luminophores can be chosen to absorb different wavelengths of sunlight. This was enabled by the materials work, since nanocrystals in different matrix materials could be stacked on top of one another. We showed here that a bilayer LSC of CdSe/CdS nanocrystals on Si nanocrystals is useful for increasing the absorption of the Si nanocrystals, and the ability to tune the concentrations independently makes this bilayer system useful in greenhouses since the transmission spectrum can also be tailored. We also examined the effects of different tandem configurations, as well as the design rules for different nanocrystal pairs. 

 

As part of this project, several undergraduate students participated in research, and K-12 teachers were trained in LSCs to develop classroom experiments. We conducted educational studies in the introductory materials science course to identify the effects of test anxiety on performance, as well as the influence of different exam structures on reducing anxiety. We found that introducing choice (“answer 8/10 of these questions”) helped reduce stress. We also conducted surveys in the senior design course on team dynamics and student sense of belonging, and used this information to create team assessments and strategies.
